unnormalised: Okay, so, money matters, right? We all deal with it every single day, from buying chai at a stall for ₹10 to paying EMIs for that dream flat in Mumbai. And let's be honest, most of us rely on banks and good old cash to make things happen. But have you ever stopped to think about all the unsaid rules and interesting little bits of info surrounding our everyday banking and cash transactions?
normalised: Okay, so, money matters, right? We all deal with it every single day, from buying chai at a stall for rupee ten to paying E-M-I-s for that dream flat in Mumbai. And let's be honest, most of us rely on banks and good old cash to make things happen. But have you ever stopped to think about all the unsaid rules and interesting little bits of info surrounding our everyday banking and cash transactions?

unnormalised: First off, ATMs. A lifesaver when you're running low on cash at 2 AM after a late-night movie, isn’t it? But did you know there's usually a limit on how much you can withdraw per day? Banks like SBI usually cap it around Rs. 40,000, but it can vary. And those free ATM transactions? You usually get about 5 per month from other banks ATMs, after which you're charged around Rs. 20+GST. Worth keeping in mind!
normalised: First off, A-T-M-s. A lifesaver when you're running low on cash at two A-M after a late-night movie, isn’t it? But did you know there's usually a limit on how much you can withdraw per day? Banks like S-B-I usually cap it around rupees forty thousand, but it can vary. And those free A-T-M transactions? You usually get about five per month from other banks A-T-M-s, after which you're charged around rupees twenty plus G-S-T. Worth keeping in mind!

unnormalised: Now, let's talk cash deposits. We all know you can deposit cash at your bank branch, but there are limits here too. For instance, if you're depositing over Rs. 50,000 in cash, you'll usually need to provide your PAN card details. It's a KYC (Know Your Customer) thing, meant to prevent dodgy dealings. And speaking of KYC, make sure your Aadhaar and PAN are linked to your bank account - deadlines for that have been extended many times, but it’s still essential.

And speaking of K-Y-C, make sure your Aadhaar and P-A-N are linked to your bank account - deadlines for that have been extended many times, but it’s still essential.

unnormalised: Then there's the world of online transactions. UPI has totally revolutionized how we send and receive money, hasn't it? From paying the local sabziwala Rs. 20 for coriander to transferring Rs. 25,000 to your bhai for his birthday, it's all done with a few taps on your phone. But even UPI has its limits. Most banks cap daily UPI transactions at Rs. 1 lakh, though some might offer higher limits. Also, remember those pesky transaction charges on credit card spends? Some merchants still add them on, even though it's often discouraged. Check your bill carefully!

But even U-P-I has its limits. Most banks cap daily U-P-I transactions at rupees one lakh, though some might offer higher limits. Also, remember those pesky transaction charges on credit card spends? Some merchants still add them on, even though it's often discouraged. Check your bill carefully!

unnormalised: And what about foreign currency? If you're planning a trip abroad, say to the US, and you're exchanging ₹ for USD, remember to shop around for the best exchange rate. Different banks and forex dealers offer slightly different rates. Also, keep in mind that you usually need to declare if you're carrying more than USD 5,000 in cash when travelling out of India.

unnormalised: Finally, a little tip for all you online shoppers. Keep an eye out for those cashback offers and discounts! Websites like Amazon and Flipkart frequently offer cashback on transactions made using certain credit cards or UPI. You could save a few hundred, maybe even a few thousand rupees, just by being a little savvy. For example, a recent sale had a 10% instant discount up to Rs. 1500 on HDFC bank cards.
